Text: You're currently reading this article in Cook County, Illinois your state has an average concentration of 9.6 micrograms of PM2.5 per cubic meter of air in 2018 which is 5.0 highest in the country. That is under the EPA's annual standard of 12 micrograms per cubic meter, though research has suggested that any amount of PM2.5 in the air can lead to greater mortality. It's also higher than that year's national average of 8.16 micrograms per cubic meter. Your area may be more polluted than average if it contains a high amount of vehicle traffic, as engine combustion is a main source of PM2.5 in the air. According to the Federal Highway Administration, drivers in Illinois purchased around 4,873,906,852 gallons of gas in 2018, which ranks at 9.0 highest in the country. Consistently high levels of PM2.5 can cause respiratory illnesses like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and lung cancer. The American Lung Association estimates there were 612,051 cases of adult chronic lung disease, which includes asthma and COPD.
